The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One is non-discriminating and free from discriminating differences in all places, neither inferior, nor middling, nor superior.
Thus, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
All dharmas are without discrimination and free from discrimination, neither inferior, nor middling, nor superior.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are unobtainable.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
That which is said to be the unobtainability of all dharmas is the equality of all dharmas;
That which is said to be the equality of all dharmas is the abiding in equality;
That which is said to be the abiding in equality is precisely non-movement;
That which is said to be non-movement is the non-reliance of all dharmas;
That which is said to be the non-reliance of all dharmas is the non-abiding of the mind in concentration;
That which is said to be the non-abiding of the mind in concentration is precisely non-arising;
That which is said to be non-arising is precisely non-production.
If one sees in this way, then the mind and mental factors are ultimately non-inverted;

If one does not give rise to conceptual proliferation, then one does not engage in any dharmas.ğŸ”½If one does not proliferate and does not engage, then one is not in birth and death;

One who accords with all dharmas cannot be moved within the nature of dharmas;
If one cannot be moved within the nature of dharmas, then one attains the nature of dharmas;
If one attains the nature of dharmas, then there is nothing to attain.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas arise in dependence on causes and conditions.
If all dharmas arise in dependence on causes and conditions, then they are always unborn;
If they are always unborn, then they are always unobtainable;
If they are always unobtainable, then one attains the dharma of reality;
If one attains the dharma of reality, then one does not abide together with any dharmas;
If one does not abide with all dharmas, then one does not abide with them;
if one does not abide, then one is neither existent nor nonexistent;
if one is neither existent nor nonexistent, then one abides in the Dharma;
if one abides in the Dharma, then one practices and contemplates the Dharma;
if one practices and contemplates the Dharma, then there is not a single Dharma that is not a Buddha-Dharma.
Why is this?
Because one realizes the emptiness of all dharmas.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!

In this way, emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, non-action, non-practice, non-reliance, non-arising, non-grasping, and non-abiding - realizing such dharmas is called bodhi.
Bodhi is called the practice and contemplation of the Dharma.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!
As for practicing right mindfulness, not grasping or rejecting is called right mindfulness.
Not observing or being different is called practice;
Not attached, not bound, not liberated, is called practice;
Not going, not coming, is called practice.
Manjushri!
For one who practices right mindfulness, there is no practice, no benefit, no fruition, and no realization.
Why is it so?
Manjushri!
Because the mind's intrinsic nature is pure, the mind is defiled by the afflictions of adventitious dust, yet the intrinsically pure mind is not defiled.
And that intrinsically pure mind itself is without defilement, and there is no one who is defiled.
Because there is no counteractive Dharma there, by what Dharma can the counteractive means eliminate these afflictions?
Why is it so?
That purity is not pure, it is originally pure.
If it is originally pure, then it is unborn;
If it is unborn, then it is undefiled;
If one is not defiled, then one is not a dharma apart from defilements;
If one is a dharma apart from defilements, then one has extinguished all defilements.
By what dharma does one extinguish all defilements?
That which is unborn.
If it is unborn, then it is bodhi.
Bodhi is called equality;
Equality is called true suchness;
True suchness is called non-differentiation;
Non-differentiation is called abiding in the true reality of all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«!

If it is neither conditioned nor unconditioned, and is not a dharma of duality, then it is true suchness.

Entering all dharmas, the gate of existence and the gate of non-existence.
